page.title: 12THE HERMITAGE AT WARKWORTH
page.content: Half a mile upstream from Warkworth Castle is the{Hermitage,}situated in a {secluded spot}by the side of the Coquet. It{consists of three rooms {hewn out of the solid rock}overhanging the river, and is reached by{a flight {of steps,}also cut out of stone. The {chapel is carved in elegant Gothic {design}and contains{the tomb of a lady along with{a hermit sculptured on the {walls,}kneeling at the foot of the tomb, his head on his right hand. The {history of the Hermitage is enveloped {in mystery,}but generally it is accepted that the first hermit was {Bertram of Bothal,}who mistakenly killed his own brother and Isabel of Widdrington, whom he loved. Both were escaping in disguise from a Scottish castle.{Today the Hermitage can be {reached by boat from the opposite bank {of the river Coquet.
